Title.evidence: Two-Stage Goal-Directed Crystalloid vs. Colloid Fluid Therapy in Laparoscopic Hepatectomy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: The sample size was calculated to detect a 6-point difference in QoR-15 scores, assuming α = 0.05 and 1-β = 0.8.

Participants.evidence: 116 patients aged 18-65 years, ASA I-III, were randomised 1:1 to receive either balanced salt solution with 6% hydroxyethyl starch (colloid group) or balanced salt solution alone (crystalloid group).

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either balanced salt solution with 6% hydroxyethyl starch (colloid group) or balanced salt solution alone (crystalloid group).

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed the effects of two-stage goal-directed crystalloid versus colloid fluid therapy on postoperative recovery quality in laparoscopic hepatectomy patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Quality of Recovery-15 (QoR-15) score at 24 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation used a random number table, with allocation concealed via opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding included patients, outcome assessors, and statisticians.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 116 patients aged 18-65 years, ASA I-III, were randomised 1:1

Number_Analysed.evidence: 58 patients were analysed per group using a per-protocol approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference was found in QoR-15 scores between groups (p > 0.05).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
